texts.ru:
Aytakin B. 25 let. Ona ne zamujem i yavlyayetsya IDP personam ona pereselenec iz Fuzuli qoroda, seychas projivayet v Fuzuli regione vmeste s semyoy. Aytakin uje 5 let zanimayetsya etim biznessom skotovodstva. Etomu biznesu ona nauchilas u svoyey mami.

Seychas Aytakin nujdayetsya v 2000 AZN chtobi kupit korovi. U sebya doma ona takje prodayet yogurt , moloko, sir kotoriy delayet ona sama.
texts.en: Aytakin B. is 25 years old. She is not married and is an internally displaced person (IDP). She hails from and now lives in the city of Fuzuli, together with her family. Aytakin has worked in the cattle business for five years. She has been taught cattle rearing by her mother. At the moment, Aytakin is in need of 2000 AZN in order to purchase cattle. She sells yogurt, milk and cheese, which she produces herself, from her home.

loans.use: to purchase cows

loans.name: Carmelita

texts.en:
Carmelita C. is from the village of Wigan Cordon. She is 51 years old. Carmelita is married and has two adult-aged children. To make a living, she sells vegetables in the local community. She is also engaged in raising hogs for fattening. She has been engaged in her businesses for over five years and earns approximately $175 a month for these activities.

In 2006, Carmelita joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. 

Carmelita is requesting a new loan of 12,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be her 8th loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful micro-finance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Lucila

texts.en:
Lucila T. is from the town of Santo Niño. She is 50 years old and single. To make a living, Lucila owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. The main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Lucila is happy to be helping her family financially. She works hard to keep her land productive.

Lucila joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.She has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. 

Lucila is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to purchase seeds, fertilizers and other farm supplies. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.use: to purchase seeds, fertilizers and other farm supplies

loans.name: Yuldash

texts.ru: Рахманов Юлдаш проживает в районе Шахритус. Возраст, 38 лет. Женат, имеет 4 детей. Образование среднее. Занимается растениеводством. Арендует земельный участок, где сеет пшеницу. Этим видом деятельности занимается уже 15 лет. Кредит берет для закупа семян. На полученную прибыль он хочет устроить свадьбу сына.
texts.en: Yuldash R. lives in the Shahrituz region. He is 38 years old. He is married and has four children. He has a secondary education, and works  cultivating crops. He rents a plot of land where he grows wheat. He has been in this line of work for 15 years. He is applying for a loan in order to purchase seeds. He would like to use the profits to pay for his son's wedding.

loans.use: Purchase of seeds

loans.name: Samuela's Group

texts.en:
Samuela R. is from the village of Palattao. She is 31 years old. Samuela is the group leader of a six-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Samuela R..

Samuela is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, she owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector operating a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling frozen foods in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over a year and earns approximately $71 a month for these activities.

In 2009, Samuela joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. 

Samuela is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be her 3rd loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful micro-finance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Hasifah

texts.en:
Hasifah Namaganda is 35 years old and lives in the town of Bugiri in the Iganga region of Uganda.  She is married and has three children.  All of her children are currently in school.  She has a retail shop, which she has had for less than one year.         

To help expand her business, Hasifah has requested a loan of 2,000,000 UGX from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to purchase more items like soap.  With the help of the loan from BRAC, Hasifah hopes to generate greater profits and buy food.  In the future, Hasifah hopes to educate her children for a better life.

loans.use: to buy more items like soap to sell

loans.name: Karine

texts.en:
Karine H. has owned a clothes selling business for about 15 years. She sells woman’s, man’s and children’s clothes, which she purchase from Yerevan once a month and resell its in the Kapan trade centre. Karine works without weekends and she says she likes her business very much not only because it helps her to keep her family, but also she enjoys her work. 

Karine is married and has three children: her husband and a son lives in Russia, her older daughter is married and younger one lives with Karine in Kapan city.

Karine is seeking for a 600.000 AMD loan to buy leather outerwear to resell.

loans.use: To buy leather outerwear to resell

loans.name: Raquel May

texts.en:
Raquel May B. is from the village of Wigan Cordon. She is 26 years old. Raquel May is single. To make a living, Raquel May owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from raising pigs for fattening and sale. Raquel May has been engaged in her business for over 6 years and earns approximately 4000 PHP when she sells one of her raised pigs.

In 2010, Raquel May joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Raquel May has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase livestock feed & other supplies. Raquel May is requesting a new loan of 7000 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock feed & other supplies. This loan will be the 2nd loan taken out by Raquel May from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand the business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase livestock feed & other supplies

loans.name: Marife's Group

texts.en:
Marife E. is from the village of Gango, Ozamis City, Misamis Occidental. She is 39 years old, married, and has one school-aged child. Marife is the group leader of a four-member group loan offered by PMPC. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Marife E.’s Group.

To make a living, Marife owns and operates a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Marife has been engaged in her business for more than fifteen years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Marife joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marife has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Marife is requesting a new loan of 14,900 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and working capital. This loan will be the third taken out by Marife from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living condition of her family.

About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. 

About Group Loans 

In a group loan, each member of the group receives an individual loan but is part of a group of individuals bound by a group guarantee. Under this arrangement, each member of the group supports one another and is responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or default.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory and working capital

loans.name: Morumbwa Kwamboka

texts.en:
Morumbwa Kwamboka E. is a 32 year old married lady and has three children aged 12, 10 and six years respectively. Morumbwa is a vegetable seller and she had been doing this for the last six years taking home a profit of Kshs 3,000 per month. Her other source of income is her husband’s income as he is employed elsewhere.

Morumbwa is a New client at KADET LTD and she has currently applied for her first loan of Khs.10,000. She plans to use the money from this loan to add more stock of vegetables and fruits. She anticipates an increase in profit from the boost of stock which she will use to improve the living standards of her family and pay school fees for her children.

She is a very hardworking lady who hopes that in future she will be able to have a large scale grocery.

loans.use: To Purchase  vegetables and fruits to sell

loans.name: Zipora Kanna

texts.en:
Zipora Kanna M. is 34 years old and lives in the town of Bugiri in the Iganga region of Uganda.  She is married and has 3 children.  All of her children are currently in school.  Zipora has a grocery business which she has had for less than one year.         

To help expand her business, Zipora has requested a loan of 1,500,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to purchase more items like sugar.  With the help of the loan from BRAC, Zipora hopes to generate greater profits and pay school fees.  In the future, Zipora hopes to educate her children to a higher level.

loans.use: To buy more supplies of sugar

loans.name: Khursheed's Group

texts.en:
Khursheed lives in a 2 room brick house in a small city called Jaranwala with her family. Jaranwala is located in Punjab Pakistan and known for its agriculture industry. She moved here after her marriage.

She operates a grocery store at her home. She has made one of her rooms into a grocery shop where she offers daily use items such as cooking oils, rice, lentils, spices etc to her customers.  Her husband, M. R. is a laborer by profession. His work is not guaranteed as some times earns good income and sometimes comes back home without anything in his pocket. That was the reason that forced Khursheed to start a grocery shop because she needed a constant source of income. 

She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner, Asasah for her grocery business. With the loan, she will buy daily use items to stock her shop.She started doing this work 5 years ago and understands the customer demand in her area. She is hopeful that she will be able to earn better income from her business after this investment. 

Khursheed is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her 2nd loan application. In a previous loan year, she has built up a good credit record and attended every meeting. 

Note: "In the photo, the lady holding the book (called Asasah Passbook) in her hands, is Khursheed".

loans.use: To buy groceries for her grocery shop

loans.name: Winnie

texts.en:
Winnie M. is 27 years old and lives in the town of Bugiri in the Iganga region of Uganda.  She is married and has 2 children.  All of her children are currently in school.  Winnie has a business of a retail shop, which she has had for 2 years.         

To help expand her business, Winnie has requested a loan of 1,500,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to purchase more items like vaseline and sugar.  With the help of the loan from BRAC, Winnie hopes to generate greater profits and to buy food.  In the future, Winnie hopes to become a wealthier family and send her children to a good school.

loans.use: to buy more inventory items like vaseline and sugar

loans.name: Juliana

texts.en:
Juliana B. is from the village of Wigan Cordon. She is 48 years old. Juliana is married and has 10 school-aged children. To make a living, Juliana owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector running a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Juliana has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 2500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Juliana joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Juliana is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the 1st loan taken out by Juliana from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand the business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Gulmurod

texts.ru: Чориев Гулмурод проживает в районе Шахритус. Возраст, 36 лет. Женат, имеет 5 детей. Образование средне – специальное, бухгалтер. По профессии не работает. Более 10 лет занимается растениеводством. Он в основном выращивает овощи и бобовые культуры. Кредит берет для закупа минеральных удобрений. Он хочет, получит хороший урожай для продажи, и расширить свою деятельность.
texts.en: Gulmurod C. lives in the Shahrituz redion. He is 36 years old and has five children. He has a secondary education, with a specialization in accounting, but he does not work in this area. For more than 10 years he has cultivated crops. He primarily grows vegetables and various legumes. He is applying for a loan to purchase mineral fertilizer. His goal is to produce a good harvest for sale and to expand his agricultural activities.

loans.use: Purchase of mineral fertilizer

loans.name: Janet

texts.en:
Janet N. is 38 years old and lives in the town of Bugiri in the Iganga region of Uganda.  She is married and has 4 children.  All of her children are currently in school.  Janet has a business of a retail shop, which she has had for 5 years.         

To help expand her business, Janet has requested a loan of 1.500.000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to purchase more items like books and bread.  With the help of the loan from BRAC, Janet hopes to generate greater profits and pay school fees.  In the future, Janet hopes to own a bigger shop in town.

loans.use: To buy more items like books and bread

loans.name: Mariles

texts.en:
Mariles N. is from the town of Plaridel. She is 42 years old. Mariles is married and has 6 adult-aged children. To make a living, Mariles owns & operates a business venture in the manufacturing sector operating a manufacturing business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from manufacturing & selling wood products to local businesses and community members. Mariles has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2000, Mariles joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Mariles has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory & working capital. Mariles is requesting a new loan of 7000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the 18th loan taken out by Mariles from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of herfamily. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Isaac

texts.en:
Isaac M. is 32 years old and lives in the town of Iganga in the Iganga region of Uganda. He is married and has no children. Isaac has a business of selling clothes, which he has had for four years.          

To help expand his business, Isaac has requested a loan of 1500000 Ugandan shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more clothes to sell. With the help of the loan from BRAC, Isaac hopes to generate greater profits and buy food. In the future, Isaac hopes to open more branches of his business.

loans.use: To buy more clothes to sell

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en: The Kiva borrower is a 39-year-old married man from Lebanon. He is living with his wife in his parents’ house. He has been involved in auto repair for 15 years and finally, in 2008, he opened his own shop, specializing in steering and wheels. He is thankful for his shop and he works hard to cover the increasing costs of food, housing and other family expenses. He is the main income provider for his family. Today, he is requesting to borrow $1200 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to purchase new wheels to expand his business operation. In the future, he hopes to enlarge his shop to earn more income and be able to buy his own house for his wife.

loans.use: To expand his inventory

loans.name: Hamuza

texts.en:
Hamuza K. is 30 years old and lives in the town of Iganga in the Iganga region of Uganda. He is married and has two children. None of his children is currently in school. Hamuza has a retail shop, which he has had for two years.          

To help expand his business, Hamuza has requested a loan of 1500000 Ugandan shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more items like cassava flour for sale. With the help of the loan from BRAC, Hamuza hopes to generate greater profits and buy food. In the future, Hamuza hopes to send his wife back to school.

loans.use: To buy more items like cassava flour for resale

loans.name: William John

texts.en:
William John O., a 43-year-old resident of Pallisa in the Iganga region of Uganda, is married and has five children, none of whom are currently in school. William has a retail shop dealing mainly in agricultural supplies, a business he has operated for less than one year.

To help expand his business, William has requested a loan of 2.000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda to purchase more items such as sugar and seeds for the farm. With the help of this loan, he hopes to generate greater profits and buy food. In the future, William plans to expand his business.

loans.use: To purchase more items such as sugar and seeds for the shop

loans.name: David

texts.en:
David I., a 45-year-old resident of Pallisa in the Iganga region of Uganda, is married and has six children, none of whom are currently in school. He has operated a restaurant for the past year.

To help expand his business, David has requested a loan of 2,500,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda to purchase and store food such as rice. With the help of the loan, he hopes to generate greater profits and buy food. In the future, David plans to expand the business.

loans.use: To buy and store more food such as rice

loans.name: Ibrahim

texts.en:
Ibrahim  is a 20-year-old single man who supports his eight siblings and two parents. He borrowed $2000 to improve his existing grocery store, which was established in 2008.

The grocery store is Ibrahim’s only source of income; accordingly he struggles to improve it to increase his monthly income to support his family.

loans.use: To improve his grocery store

loans.name: Melanie

texts.en:
Melanie T., from the town of Sto. Niño, is 29 years old, married and has two children aged six and five. To make a living, Melanie owns and operates a business venture planting and harvesting rice for sale.

Melanie joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She also likes its microinsurance program. Melanie is requesting a loan of 8000 PHP to purchase seeds, fertilizers and farming equipment. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income.

loans.use: To purchase seeds, fertilizers and farming equipment

loans.name: Lan Thi Nguyen's Group

texts.en:
Lan T. N. is 31 years old with two children who are in secondary school. She opened a shop five years ago where she serves breakfast for those who live in her village. She earns 100,000 VND per day from this activity.

As a member of SEDA’s credit program since 2004, she has been a good group leader and used loans effectively in running her business. Currently, she would like a loan of 6,322,000 VND to buy some sets of tables and desks for use by her customers.

About the Other Borrowers:

1) Phuc T. D. is 42 years old with two children who are in high school. She is a farmer. Currently, she is raising twelve pigs for meat. In order to provide feed for them, she would like a loan of 6,322,000 VND. 2) Duyen T. H. is 28 years old with two young children. She sells fresh vegetables in Coloa market. She would like a loan of 5,450,000 VND to invest in her shop. 3) Xuan T. N. is 32 years old with two children who are in secondary school. She sell sugar cane in the local market. Currently, she would like to borrow 5,014,000,VND to buy more sugar cane to meet the demands of customers during summer. 4) Thanh T. H. is 27 years old with two young children. She is a tailor whose shop has been open for three years and has been busy with customer orders. She wants to borrow 5,014,000 VND to buy more material for clothes.

loans.use: To buy some sets of tables and desks

loans.name: Perveen's Group

texts.en:
Perveen (shown holding the book) lives in Jaranwala, a small city located in Punjab Pakistan and known for its agriculture industry. She has been residing with her family in a two-room brick house in the area of Islampura for the past 13 years. Perveen has four daughters and one son, four of whom are students. She wants them to complete their education to ensure their futures.

Perveen's husband, M. T., is a private entrepreneur dealing in unstitched clothes. He has been selling clothes to many cloth shops in various areas of the community for the past 10 years by going about on his four-wheeled cart. Having developed a large clientèle, his sales allow him to meet the financial expenses of the family.

Perveen has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her husband’s business so that he can buy unstitched clothes in bulk to increase both his sales and his income.

Perveen is a regular loan user of Asasah, and this is her second loan application. With her previous loan she established good credit behavior and attended every meeting.

loans.use: To buy unstitched clothes for reselling

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en:
Teresita H. is from the village of Wigan Cordon. She is 48 years old. Teresita is married. To make a living, Teresita raises livestock, primarily pigs for fattening and sale. Teresita has been engaged in her business for more than two years and earns approximately 4000 PHP when she sells one of her pigs.

In 2006, Teresita joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her business and living situation. Teresita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 16000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. Teresita is requesting a new loan of 18000 PHP, which she will use to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. This will be the eighth loan taken by Teresita from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the loan to improve and expand her business. 

About ASKI:
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase livestock feed and other supplies

loans.name: Lilibeth Cabang Group

texts.en:
Lilibeth C. is from the village of Allinguigan 1st. She is 31 years old. Lilibeth is the group leader of a 10-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Lilibeth C..

Lilibeth is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Lilibeth owns and operates a general store. Lilibeth has been engaged in her business for more than two years and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Lilibeth joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her business and living situation. Lilibeth has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Lilibeth is requesting a new loan of 7000 PHP, which she will use to purchase more products to sell. This will be the second loan taken by Lilibeth from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the loan to improve and expand her business. 

About ASKI:
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Uk

texts.en: Uk S., 26, is married and resides with her husband and three children in Takeo Province, Cambodia, an area known for pre-Angkorean temples. S. sells fruit, earning an income of 5 USD per day. Her husband sells vegetables, earning an income of about 6 USD per day. The family has to spend 83 USD on food, 10 USD on electricity, and 20 USD on other necessary expenses every month. S. is requesting a loan of 1000 USD to purchase more fruits and vegetables to resell. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her second loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy more fruits and vegetables to resell

loans.name: Alice

texts.en:
Alice N., 45 years old and married to Gilbert Okibiro, is the mother of three children: Joshua, 25, Rosemary, 22, and Kevin, 21 years of age.

Alice has a retail shop and is applying for her second loan of Kshs 50,000 to buy one sack of sugar to add to her stock. Her business having improved since her first loan, Alice's monthly income is now Kshs 10,000. Her profits will be used to pay school fees for her children, who are all attending university.

Alice desires to open another shop near the shopping center and also expand the current one into a wholesale operation.

loans.use: To buy one sack of sugar

loans.name: Chhen

texts.en: Chhen K., 30, is married and resides with her husband and four children in Takeo Province, Cambodia, an area known for Pre-Angkorean temples. K. is a farmer, earning an income of USD 2 per day. Her husband sells sand, earning an income of about USD 5 per day. The family has to spend USD 50 on food, USD 5 on electricity, and USD 20 on other necessary expenses every month.  K. is requesting a loan of USD 1200 to purchase more sand to resell. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.  This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: buy more sand to sell

loans.name: Jose

texts.en:
Jose B. Jr. is from the village of Bungad, San Pablo, Isabela. He is 37 years old. Jose is married and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Jose owns & operates a business venture in the food sector making & selling food. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from preparing and selling ice cream. loans.name: Dushekan's Group

texts.en:
Dushekan K. is the leader of this group. She is 54 and a widow. She has raised five daughters; four of them are married and live separately with their families and the youngest daughter studies at school.  In 2007 Dushekan’s daughters collected money and presented her two calves. And since that moment Dushekan has been engaged in cattle breeding.  With money received from the loan she wants to purchase cattle in order to resell it a higher price after fattening.  In the future she wants to increase the number of cattle and then build a proper shed.

Asyl B. is the treasurer of the group. She is 28 and married. She has three daughters. The first daughter is at school and the others are not yet; they are preschool age (under seven).  Asyl is engaged in cattle breeding and her husband is a private driver. Asyl started to breed cattle in 2005 with the initial investment of 25,000 soms.  She hopes to obtain the loan because she needs money to purchase two more farm animals for breeding. 

Damira J., 43, is married. She has two sons and a daughter. All the children are students. Damira and her husband are engaged in cattle breeding. They started this activity in 2002. With money received from the loan, Damira wants to purchase two calves in order to increase her herd.

Taalaibek B., 43, is married. He has two daughters and three sons.  Taalaibek and his wife are farmers. They breed cattle and cultivate different fruits and vegetables. With money received from the loan, Taalaibek wants to purchase cattle and then resell the animals a higher price after fattening.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

texts.en:
Joann R. is from the village of Minlagas, San Luis, Gingoog City. She is 30 years old. Joann is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Joann owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from planting & harvesting  a variety of vegetables like eggplant for sale. Joann has been engaged in her business for over 8 years and earns approximately 7000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Joann joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Joann is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings & young crops to raise. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Joann from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

loans.name: Kenneth

texts.en:
Kenneth O. is 35 years old and married to Lydia Auma; they have five children who are all under 18 years old. They live in Kisumu city.

Kenneth has a business for making bricks and has been doing it for the past four years. He has a huge clientele as many building construction companies order from him. He is in dire need of working capital to be able to meet the demand of his customers. He intends to use the money to buy materials for making the bricks. His monthly income is Kshs 20,000. 

His desire is to venture into a chicken-rearing business to run alongside the brick business.

loans.use: Buy building materials and stone for making bricks

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Lebanese Kiva borrower is a 38-year-old married man and the father of two children. He is the main income provider for his family. He has been running his own farm since 2006 and he also sells seeds and fertilizers. This man uses plastic tents to grow his crops. These tents allow him to better monitor product quality as well as grow his crops for more months during the year. He works independently in his business. 

Today, he is requesting a loan of $1,200 from the Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to purchase needed supplies and additional tents for his agricultural work. He estimates that the loan will help increase his profits by fifteen percent.

loans.use: To purchase needed supplies and additional tents for agricultural work

To make a living, Rutchelyn owns and operates a retail business venture running a sari-sari (variety) shop. The main source of income from the business comes primarily from selling food and daily use products in the local community. Rutchelyn has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month from these activities.

Rutchelyn joined Hagdan sa Pag-uswag Foundation, Inc. (HSPFI) in 2010 to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rutchelyn is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Rutchelyn from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business.

loans.name: Arlene

texts.en:
Arlene M. is from the village of Bungad. She is 24 years old and married with two school-aged children. To make a living, Arlene owns and operates a manufacturing business. The main source of income from the business comes primarily from manufacturing and selling bath soaps to community members. Arlene has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month from these activities.

Arlene joined Alalay sa Kaunlaran, Inc. (ASKI) in 2009 to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Arlene has successfully repaid a previous loan of 13,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase raw materials to manufacture additional products. Arlene is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP which will be used for the same purpose. This loan will be the 4th loan taken out by Arlene from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support her immediate family members.

loans.name: Yolanda

texts.en:
Yolanda B. is from the town of Sto. Niño. She is 51 years old,  married, and has five children, some of whom still attend school. To make a living, Yolanda tills a farm where she plants and harvests rice crops for sale. She also raises ducks. Yolanda aims to have her children finish college and have bright futures. She says that she and her husband work hard to sustain their family's needs and their children's education.

Yolanda joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Yolanda has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Yolanda is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP, which will be used to buy seeds, fertilizers, and duck feed. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the living conditions of her family.

loans.use: To buy seeds, fertilizers, and duck feed

loans.name: Mastura's Group

texts.en:
Mastura N. is the leader of the group.  She is 38, married, and has three children, all of whom attend school.  Mastura works as a nurse and her husband went to work in Russia.  Mastura also grows tobacco and breeds livestock animals for additional income. Three years ago with the initial investment of 4,000 soms, she bought four goats for breeding and now she has 20. With money received from the loan, she wants to purchase more livestock animals for breeding. In the future, she wants to provide her children with good education.

Holishon K. is the treasurer of the group. She is 36 and works in the Department of Registration. Holishon has started to breed livestock; she hopes to obtain the loan to purchase five sheep for breeding. 

Olmahon T. is 45, married, and has five children. Olmahon works as a security guard at school and her husband is a post officer. Olmahon and her husband also breed cattle and grow tobacco.  With money received from the loan, they want to purchase a cow for breeding. 

Gulchehra T. is 41, divorced, and has two sons; the first son is handicapped and the second attends school.  Gulchehra works as a nurse; she also breeds livestock animals for additional income.  With money received from the loan. she wants to purchase three sheep for breeding. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious, and socially-focused microfinance institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase livestock animals

texts.en:
Divina B. is from the village of Baculod, Alcala, Cagayan. She is 33 years old. Divina is the leader of an eight-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Divina is married and has two school-age children. To make a living, Divina makes and sells food. The main source of income for the business comes from preparing and selling carabao milk candies in the local community. Divina has been engaged in her business for over 12 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Divina joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Divina is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase the raw ingredients needed to make products to sell. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Divina from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to save as a reserve for future emergencies.

The main source of income for the business comes from serving a variety of different meals to customers in the local community. loans.name: Thon

texts.en:
Thon N. is a 56-year-old married mother who presently lives in the best province of Kompong Chhnang. She is a local farmer and also a tailor in her village. Thon N. currently generates an income of approximately US$ 2 per day by sewing clothes.  Thon N. is always hired by neighbors to sew new clothes for their wedding parties and other ceremonies. She also shares her sewing knowledge with her trainees for a fee. The family includes five devoted children, three of whom are single and two are married.

N.'s business has been running well for many years now but she still requires more materials to support her service. Thon N. is taking out her loan to buy more cloth, and with the remainder of the  funds to purchase fertilizer.

loans.use: To buy more cloth and with the remainder to purchase fertilizer

loans.name: Kholoud

texts.en:
Kholoud is a housewife and mother of three sons and lives in Bethlehem.  Kholoud's husband, who appears with her in the picture posted here, is a construction worker. He builds houses in the city of Bethlehem and in Beit Sahour and Beit Jala, which are the neighboring cities of Bethlehem.

Khouloud's husband works for a workshop with a team of builders. He wants to start doing freelance construction work in addition to his work with the workshop, so Kholoud took a $1,000 loan from FATEN for this purpose. Kholoud's husband's freelancing will increase the family's income.

loans.use: To purchase construction tools

loans.name: Kalyskan's Group

texts.en:
Kalyskan T. is the leader of this group.  She is 39 and divorced.  She has a son who studies at university. Ten years ago with the initial investment of 2000 soms, Kalyskan rented a sewing machine and started to provide sewing services.  She takes orders and sews drapes and women’s bathrobes. In this way she earns 3440 soms per month.  She hopes to obtain the loan because she needs money to purchase fabrics and materials for sewing. In the future she wants to purchase a flat for her son.

Monuskan T. is the treasurer of the group. She is 37 and married. She has two daughters and a son.  All the children are at school. In order to make money Monuskan breeds livestock and her husband works in construction. Monuskan started her activity five years ago with the initial investment of 2000 soms. With money received from the loan she wants to purchase livestock for breeding. 

Zulaika A., 38, is a widow. She has three sons; all of them are at school. Zulaika breeds livestock to earn money. She resells sheep after fattening, and in this way she makes 2000 soms per month.   She hopes to obtain the loan because she needs money to purchase sheep in order to increase her flock.  In the future she wants to save money and purchase household appliances in order to improve her living conditions.

Kubatbek K., 36, is married. He has a daughter who is at school. Kabatbek and his wife breed livestock; they resell sheep after fattening. In this way they make about 2000 soms per month.  With money received from the loan, Kabatbek wants to purchase livestock for breeding. In the future he wants to start building a new house.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). loans.name: Phem

texts.en:
Phem C., age 60, lives in the province of Kompong Chhnang, which is the best territory for farming. Phem C. is a married woman who is devoted to her six children for whom she is responsible. Phem C.’s husband (pictured) is the chief of a construction team. 

Phem C. possesses a few farms that she inherited from her grandmother. She grows crops on them, and she also gets good results from her farming. Her husband often helps her to grow crops. She said that presently her toilet is getting old, and it is not comfortable for her family to use.  So Phem C. would like to request a loan from Kiva to buy construction materials for mending the old toilet.

loans.use: To buy construction materials for mending the old toilet

loans.name: Benkadi Group

texts.fr:
Les 4 femmes du groupe Benkadi sont toutes mariées, avec une moyenne d’âge  qui  tourne autour de 39 ans, elles ont en moyenne 8 enfants et vivent dans des grandes familles traditionnelles dans la ville de San (région de Ségou, république du Mali).
Elles sont à leur 1er prêt solidaire avec l’institution et se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage et de parenté. 
Elles exercent presque la même activité d’achat et de vente de condiments et produits alimentaires. 
Fanta S., la présidente du groupe détient un kiosque au bord du goudron uniquement pour la vente de pâte d’arachide. 
Elle s’approvisionne en gros auprès des sœurs catholiques pour revendre en détail, au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle essentiellement constituée de femmes. 
Elle compte sur un bénéfice mensuel de 13500FCFA par mois qui la permettra de rembourser le prêt, venir en aide à son époux et réinvestir dans l’entreprise. 
Dans l’avenir Fanta S. compte venir au prêt individuel  pour être elle-même productrice de pâte d’arachide.
texts.en:
The four women in the Benkadi group are all married and are on average 39 years old. They all have about 8 children and live in large traditional families in the town of San (in the Ségou region, republic of Mali).
This is  their first solidarity loan with the organisation and they became acquainted through family ties and living in the same neighbourhood.
They all practice almost the same activity of buying and selling condiments and foodstuffs.
Fanta S., the president of the group owns a stall on the side of the road solely for the sale of peanut paste.
She buys her supplies wholesale from some catholic nuns, to sell retail for cash or on credit to a clientele that is essentially made up of women.
She is counting on a monthly profit of 13500FCFA  which will enable her to repay the loan, help her husband, and reinvest in the business.
In the future Fanta S. plans to request an individual loan in order to become a producer of peanut paste herself.

loans.use: Purchase of peanut paste

loans.name: Lilian

Lilian is 27 years old and is married to a husband who is a security guard. She has 4 children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to expand her business.
