loans.name: Arif

texts.ru:
Arif K. 53 qoda. On jenat i imeyet 2 detey, doch kotoroy 20 let ona uchitsya v universitete i sin 19 let kotoriy toje uchitsya v universitete i pomoqayet otcu po rabote. Arif yavlyayetsya IDP personom on pereselenec iz Fuzuli regiona i seychas projivayet v Fuzuli regione, pasolok Dilagar vmeste s semyoy.

Arif uje 2 qoda kak zanimayestya etim biznessom skotovodstva. Etomu biznessu yeqo nauchil dyadya. Eto uje vtoroy ssud Arifa v pervuyu ssudu on bral 1200$, on ochen blaqodaren lenderam za ssudu. Posle etoy ssudi on razvil svoy bizness  posle cheqo on reshil izmenit svoy bizness na bolee pribilniy , i seychas kak vidite na fotoqrafii on zanimayetsya skotovodstvom. Seychas on nujdayetsya v 2000 AZN chtobi kupit korovi dlya razvitiya svoyeqo novoqo biznessa.

http://partners.kiva.org/lend/7138
texts.en:
Arif K. is 53 years old. He is married, with two children: a 20-year old daughter who is a university student and a 19-year old son, also a university student, who helps his father with the work. Arif is an Internally Displaced Person; he is a refugee from the Fuzuli Region and now lives in the village of Dilagar, Fuzuli Region, together with his family.

Arif has been raising cattle for two years. He learned this work from his uncle. This is already  a second loan for Arif. He took out a loan of $1200 in the past and is very grateful to lenders for that loan. After the first loan he was able to grow his business, after which he decided to switch to a more profitable occupation. Now, as you can see on the photo, he raises cattle. At present he needs 2000 AZN in order to buy a cow for his new line of business. 

http://partners.kiva.org/lend/7138

loans.use: Purchasing a cow

loans.name: Tarapwe

texts.en: Tarapwe F.  is currently in the business of selling charcoal and local brew at her home site and is requesting a loan to stock more bags of charcoal to sell.  Tarapwe is 35 years old and is married to a husband who is a driver. She has one child and her child does not go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a real shop.

loans.use: Stock more bags of charcoal to sell

loans.name: Benkan Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe Benkan sont toutes  mariées. Leur moyenne d’âge  se situe autour de 38 ans et elles ont en moyenne 7 enfants. Les femmes du groupe Benkan vivent dans des grandes familles traditionnelles dans la ville de San (région de Ségou, république du Mali). 
Elles se sont connues à travers des voisinage et  des liens de parenté. 
Elles excellent dans l’achat vente de condiments alimentaires et diverses petites marchandises. 
Assa MORIKE T. qui est la présidente du groupe est une vendeuse de riz au grand marché de SAN, qui compte acheter 3 tonnes de riz. Elle s’approvisionne avec les producteurs de la ville et revend en détail et au comptant. Cette activité est très rentable pour elle.
Elle espère réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 29000 FCFA tandis que les autres membres comptent sur un bénéfice 27000 FCFA qui sera utilisé pour le remboursement  du prêt  et les dépenses courantes de la famille.
texts.en:
The women of the Benkan group are all married. They average 38 years of age and seven  children each. They live in large traditional families in the city of San (in the Ségou region of Mali).
They know each other as neighbors and relatives.

They excel in the buying and selling food condiments and various small goods. 

Assa MORIKE T., president of the group, sells rice at the big market of San. She plans to buy three tons of rice. She gets her stocks from local rice growers and sells at retail, for cash. This is a very profitable business for her.

She hopes to earn a monthly profit of 29,000 FCFA, while other members expect to make 27,000 FCFA each month, to be used to repay the loan and cover family expenses.

loans.use: Purchase of rice

loans.name: Syrgaiym's Group

texts.en: Syrgaiym N. is the leader of the group. She is 45 and divorced. She has a daughter and a son; both of them are as school. In order to make money, Syrgaiym rents a shop and sells convenience goods. In this way, she earns 8,000 soms per month. She hopes to obtain the loan because she needs money to purchase a variety of convenience goods in order to increase the turnover of her business. Aisuluu E. is the treasurer of the group. She is 40 and married. She has a daughter and a son. The son studies at university and the daughter is at school. Aisuluu works in the Department of Registration and her husband is a private driver. With money received from the loan, she wants to purchase a computer. In the future, she wants to provide her children a good education. Omurbek A., 39, is married. He has three daughters. Three years ago, with the initial investment of 3,000 soms, Omurbek and his wife started to breed livestock. With money received from the loan, they want to purchase more livestock for breeding. Abdugalim A., 49, is married. He has three sons and two daughters. Abdugalin is a private driver and his wife works as a teacher. Abdugalim wants to start breeding cattle. With money received from the loan, he wants to purchase a cow. Where Did This Loan Come From? This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused microfinance institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple "P" bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase convenience goods

loans.name: Liza

texts.en: Liza M. is from the village of Brgy. Vista Alegre, Bayombong, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 45 years old. Liza is married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Liza operates a tailoring business. The main source of income for the business comes from providing general alteration and tailoring services to local community members. Liza has been engaged in her business for over 13 years and earns approximately 4,000 Philippines pesos (PHP) a month from it. In 2007, Liza joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Liza has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional fabrics and materials. Liza is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional tailoring equipment such as needles and thread. This loan will be the ninth loan taken out by Liza from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional tailoring equipment such as needles and thread

loans.name: Edna's Group

texts.en: Edna A. is from the village of Baybayog, Alcala, Cagayan. She is 41 years old. Edna is the group leader of a seven-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. Edna is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Edna operates a general store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Edna has been engaged in her business for over seven years and earns approximately 4,000 Philippines pesos (PHP) a month from it. In 2010, Edna joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Edna is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the first loan taken out by Edna from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 34 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Danaya Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe Danaya sont toutes mariées, ont en moyenne 34 ans, 4 enfants et vivent dans des grandes familles traditionnelles dans la ville de Yangasso (région de Ségou, république du Mali). 
Elles se sont connues à travers des voisinage et  des liens de parenté. Elles exercent diverses activités génératrices de revenus telles la vente de condiments alimentaires, de riz et de divers autres articles. 
Ces femmes travaillent avec Soro Yiriwaso il y a une année. Elles sont à leur 2e prêt solidaire et Marama C.  qui est une vendeuse ambulante de tissus et wax, compte acheter avec son prêt, quelques pièces de pagnes wax. 
Elle s’approvisionne à BAMAKO mensuellement pour revendre aux femmes et aux hommes en détail  à crédit en espèce. 
Elle espère réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 12.500FCFA et les autres membres du groupe comptent chacune sur un bénéfice de 11.500FCFA, qui permettra de rembourser le prêt,  venir en aide aux conjoints et d’agrandir son entreprise.
texts.en:
The women of the Danaya group are all married, of an average age of 34 years old, have 4 children, and live in large traditional families in the town of Yangasso (Ségou region in the republic of Mali).
They became acquainted through living in the same neighbourhood and family ties. They practice various income generating activities such as the sale of food seasoning, rice and other goods.
These women joined Soro Yiriwaso a year ago. This is their second solidarity loan and Marama C. who is an itinerant saleswoman of fabric and wax print textiles,plans to buy items of traditional wax clothing with her loan.
She purchases her supplies at Bamako every month and sells her merchandise to both men and women as retail for cash.
She hopes to make a monthly profit of 12.500FCFA and the other members of the group each hope for a profit of 11.500FCFA, which will enable them to repay the loan, help their spouses and expand their activities.

loans.use: Purchase of traditional wax dyed clothing

loans.name: Betty

texts.en: Betty A. is currently in the business of selling bread and other food items at the market and is requesting a loan to stock more goods to sell. Betty is 30 years old and is married to a soldier. She has 4 children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to expand her business.

loans.use: Stock more goods to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en: This Kiva borrower is a 22 year old single man from Lebanon. He is a relatively new business owner - he has worked as a sanitary worker repairing toilets, faucets, etc. for the past five years. As per the majority of Lebanese men, he helps his family with the household expenses. All family members need to cooperate together to be able to meet the heavy expenses of daily life. Today, he is requesting to borrow $1000 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to improve his work and purchase more needed tools. In the future, he is hoping to open a shop selling janitorial supplies. He feels positive about his business potential for the coming year.

loans.use: To improve his work and purchase more needed tools.

loans.name: Hong Thi Hoang's Group

texts.en:
Hong T. H. is 56 years old with two children who are who are married. She is a farmer and her main activities are growing rice and vegetables and raising chickens. She has been a successful farmer for many years. She has been a SEDA credit client since 2006 and has effectively used loans to expand her business. Hong is requesting a loan of 6,322,000 VND to buy fertilizer and pesticide.

Hanh T. N. is 36 years old and has two children who are in secondary school. She runs a dress shop and makes dresses for customers in her village. Hanh is requesting a loan of 6,322,000 VND to buy clothes.

Sau T. N. is 52 years old. She is raising ten pigs for meat and is requesting a loan of 7,164,000 VND to buy food for them.

Ton T. L. is 60 years old with two children. She runs a shop that serves breakfast. She wants to borrow 7,194,000 VND to buy cooking tools to make her service better.

Mai T. D. is 44 years old with three children who attend high school. She is raising 200 chickens to provide eggs for saL.. Mai is requesting a loan of 6,322,000 VND to buy food.

Thanh T. N. is 25 years old with two small children. She is raising 300 chickens for meat and is requesting a loan of 6,322,000 VND to improve her chicken coop.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and pesticide

loans.name: Hang

texts.en: Hang Y. is a 53 year old widowed villager who lives in Kompong Chhnang province. She is a mother whose children are all single and live with her. Her husband died of senility years ago. Hang Y. has worked in agriculture for many years. All her income comes from planting crops on her farmland. Hang Y. usually generates around $1.50 of profit a day to meet the needs of her family. For the upcoming rainy season, Hang Y. needs capital to purchase many fertilizers for her crops to grow well.

loans.use: To purchase many fertilizers for her crops to grow well.

loans.name: Hing

texts.en:
Hing P., 48, is married and resides with her husband and five children in Takeo Province, Cambodia, an area known for pre-angkorean Temples. P. is a farmer and raises cows, earning an income of USD 2.50 per day. Her husband is a farmer, earning an income of about USD 2.50 per day. The family has to spend USD 50.00 on food, USD 15.00 on children's education, and USD 10.00 on other necessary expenses every month. P. is requesting a loan of USD 1,200 to purchase a motorbike for the children to use to commute to work.

In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia. Hing appears in the photograph with her husband.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike.

loans.name: Finesse Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe Finesse sont toutes  mariées et ont une moyenne d’âge de 33 ans et 5  enfants. Les femmes du groupe Finesse vivent dans des grandes familles traditionnelles dans la ville de San (région de Ségou, république du Mali). Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage et de parenté. 
Elles exercent les activités de restauration et la vente de condiments alimentaires, d’habits et divers articles. Ces activités sont très rentables  pour ces femmes du groupe. 
Kotimi T., est une vendeuse de condiments alimentaires à son domicile qui compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, 2 sacs de sel de cuisine, 1 carton de cube maggi, 1 carton de concentrée  de tomate, 2kg de poivre, des oignons  et de l’ail. 
Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 18500FCFA tandis que les autres membres comptent réaliser chacune un bénéfice mensuel de 17500 FCFA, somme qui leur permettra de rembourser le prêt, de venir en aide aux conjoints et réinvestir dans l’entreprise.
texts.en: The women of the Finesse group are all married and are, on average, 33 years old with 5 children. They live in large traditional families in the city of San (Ségou region, republic of Mali). They know one another through ties of community and kinship.  They operate food preparation businesses and sell condiments, clothing and miscellaneous items. These businesses are very profitable for the women's group.  Kotimi T. sells food condiments from her home and intends to use her loan to buy 2 bags of cooking salt, 1 carton of maggi cubes, 1 carton of tomato paste, and 2kg of pepper, onions and garlic.  She expects to make a monthly profit of 18,500 CFA while other members expect to make a monthly profit of 17,500 CFA francs each, a sum that will enable them to repay the loan, help their husbands and reinvest in the business.

loans.use: To buy food condiments

loans.name: Potenciano

texts.en:
Potenciano R. is from the village of Brgy. Vista Alegre, Bayombong, Nueva Vizcaya. He is 51 years old. Potenciano is married and has 3 adult children. To make a living, Potenciano owns and operates a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling scrap metal and other used products in the local community. Potenciano has been engaged in his business for over 15 years and earns approximately 3,200 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2006, Potenciano joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Potenciano has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Potenciano is requesting a new loan of 12,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase new items to expand his product offering. This loan will be the 9th loan taken out by Potenciano from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of the borrower's family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand product offering.

loans.name: Fatima

texts.en:
Fatima L. is a 39 year old farmer with four children. She was born in a large, low-income family where she spent most of her time helping her family with farming and growing spring onions.

In 1992, Fatima got married and kept up her activity of cultivating wheat and onions. In 1998, Fatima’s family bought a house in Tokmok town, and bought bull-calves, which became their first step in a livestock breeding business. As time passed by, Fatima developed her farm with the revenues from selling meat products at the local markets, and was able to construct a barn for her cattle. Now this activity allows Fatima to earn about 10,000 KGS monthly to cover initial expenses of her children. 

She plans to use the loan of 80,000 KGS to broaden her business by purchasing cattle. With the revenues from this investment, Fatima plans to give a good education to her children. 

Bai-Tushum and Partners uses Kiva funding to target the especially vulnerable population. Bai-Tushum and Partners is one of the leading Microfinance Institutions in Kyrgyzstan. As a reliable financial partner, Bai-Tushum contributes to the economic development of the Kyrgyz Republic through the delivery of microfinance services in rural and urban areas that lead to increased employment and meet the interests of its clients and investors.

loans.use: To purchase cattle.

loans.name: Prang

texts.en:
Prang S., 36, is married and resides with her husband and four children in Takeo Province, Cambodia, an area known for pre-angkorean Temples. S. sells vegetables, earning an income of USD 3.00 per day. Her husband is a teacher, earning an income of about USD 3.00 per day. The family has to spend USD 30.00 on food, USD 20.00 on their children's education, and USD 5.00 on other necessary expenses every month.

S. is requesting a loan of USD 300 to purchase cows to raise and then sell. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy cows to raise and then sell.

loans.name: Nyubang

texts.en: Nyubang P. is currently in the business of selling bread and local brew and is requesting a loan to stock more brewing supplies. Nyubang is 39 years old and is married to a peasant. She has 3 children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a shop.

loans.use: To stock more brewing supplies.

loans.name: Lafia Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Lafia est constitué de 6 femmes toutes mariées ayant en moyenne 48 ans, 9 enfants et vivant dans des grandes familles traditionnelles Somono et Bozo dans le village de Belenithiegni, préfecture  de SAN (région de Ségou, république du Mali). 
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage et  de parenté. Elles exercent presque la même activité de vente de poissons frais et fumés. Le groupe est à son 7e prêt solidaire avec Soro Yiriwaso.      
Diaou H., la présidente du groupe s’est spécialisée dans la vente de poisson frais. 
Elle compte acheter, une quantité importante de poissons frais de tous genres, en gros avec leurs maris, frères et enfants, qui pêchent. Elle met des barres de glaces sur les gros paniers remplis de poisson frais en destination de SIKASSO. Les poissons sont revendus en demi gros chaque semaine et elle effectue le déplacement durant les périodes où la pêche rapporte beaucoup de poissons. 
Elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 47000 FCFA par mois, somme qui la permettra de rembourser le prêt, de venir en aide aux époux et réinvestir dans 
l’activité.
texts.en: The Lafia group consists of 6 married women. On average, they are 48 years old with 9 children and live in Somono and Bozo large traditional families in the village of Belenithiegni, San prefecture (Segou region, republic of Mali).  They know one another through ties of community and kinship. They are engaged in nearly the same business selling fresh and smoked fish. This is the group's seventh solidarity loan with Soro Yiriwaso.  Diaou H., president of the group, specializes in selling fresh fish.  She plans to buy wholesale a large quantity of fresh fish of all kinds from the group's husbands, brothers and children who fish. She puts blocks of ice on large baskets filled with fresh fish bound for SIKASSO. The fish are sold at retail wholesale every week, and she makes the trip during periods when the fishing yield is high.  She hopes to earn a monthly profit of 47,000 CFA per month, which will enable her to repay the loan, help the spouses and reinvest in the business.

loans.use: To buy fish

loans.name: Sao

texts.en:
Sao U., 32, is married and resides with her husband and three children in Takeo Province, Cambodia, an area known for pre-angkorean Temples. U. is a farmer, earning an income of USD 3.00 per day. Her husband sells knives, earning an income of about USD 5.00 per day. The family has to spend USD 33.00 on food, USD 20.00 on the children's education, and USD 5.00 on other necessary expenses every month.

U. is requesting a loan of USD 1,000 to purchase a motorbike to transport knives to sell. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia. U.'s husband appears in the photograph because U. was not available.

loans.use: To buy a motorobike.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To purchase a new carpet weaving frame.

loans.name: Sok

texts.en:
Sok Y., 41, is married and resides with her husband and three children in Takeo Province, Cambodia, an area known for pre-angkorean Temples. Y. weaves Cambodian traditional silk to sell, earning an income of USD 3.00 per day. Three of her children are employed at the factories, earning an income of USD 3.00 each per day to help cover the family's expenses. The family has to spend USD 25.00 on food, USD 1.50 on electricity supply, and USD 6.00 on other necessary expenses every month.

Y. is requesting a loan of USD 1,000 to purchase a motorbike for the family's use. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike for the family's use.

loans.name: Lucia

texts.en: Lucia L. is currently in the business of selling various items in the bar and is requesting a loan to stock more crates of beer and soda to sell.  Lucia is 40 years old and is married to a driver. She has 6 children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house.

loans.use: To stock more crates of beer and soda to sell.

loans.name: Sourn

texts.en:
Sourn S., 59, is married and resides with her husband and four children in Takeo Province, Cambodia, an area known for pre-angkorean Temples. S. and her husband are farmers and raise ducks at home, earning an income of USD 6.50 per day. The four children are employed at the factories, earning an income of about USD 3.00 each per day. The family has to spend USD 35.00 on food, USD 15.00 on electricity and water supplies, and USD 15.00 on other necessary expenses every month.

S. is requesting a loan of USD 1,000 to purchase a motorbike for the children to commute to work. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike.

loans.name: Yeredon Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe Yeredon sont toutes mariées, la moyenne d’âge de ces femmes se situe autour de 37 ans et elles en moyenne 4 enfants. Les  femmes du groupe Yeredon vivent dans des grandes familles traditionnelles de la ville de Yangasso (région de Ségou, république du Mali). 
Elles se sont connues à travers des relation de  voisinage et  de parenté. 
Elles exercent les activités de restauration, de vente de condiments, de bijoux et diverses marchandises.  Ces femmes sont à leur premier le prêt solidaire avec Soro Yiriwaso.
Minata K. est une restauratrice en plein cœur de Yangasso, au bord du goudron et MINATA  prépare et vend presque tous les plats Malien. Elle s’approvisionne en matières premières à la foire de Bla et de KOUTIALA.
Avec ce prêt elle compte acheter, 250 kg de riz, 15 litres d’huile alimentaire, 10kg d’oignons, 1 paquet de cube maggi et le reste pour les petits condiments. 
Elle espère sur un bénéfice de 24500FCFA, somme  qui permettra de rembourser le prêt et subvenir aux besoins familiaux.
texts.en:
The members of the Yeredon group are all married women, averaging around 37 years of age and four children. The group members live in large traditional families in the town of Yangasso (Segou Region of Mali).

They know each other as neighbors and relatives. They prepare food for sale as well as sell condiments, jewelry and miscellaneous merchandise. This is their first solidarity loan with Soro Yiriwaso.

Minata K. is a food vendor working in the  middle of Yangasso, by the “goudron” [tarmac road]. Minata cooks and sells almost all traditional Malinese plates. She stocks up on her provisions at the markets of Bla and Koutiala. With this loan she plans to purchase 250 kg [550 lbs] of rice, 15 liters [4 gal] of vegetable oil, 10 kg [22 lbs] of onions, 1 pack of “Maggi” bouillon cubes and some condiments. She hopes to achieve an income of 24,500 West African Francs, which will allow her to repay the loan and provide for the family needs.

loans.use: Purchasing ingredients for food production

loans.name: Chem

texts.en:
Chem S., 34, is married and resides with her husband and two children in Takeo Province, Cambodia, an area known for pre-angkorean Temples. S. is employed at the factory, earning an income of USD 3.50 per day. Her husband is a motor-taxi driver, earning an income of about USD 4.00 per day. The family has to spend USD 30.00 on food, USD 15.00 on electricity and water supplies, and USD 10.00 on other necessary expenses every month.

S. is requesting a loan of USD 500 to purchase a motorbike to attach to a compartment. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia. S. appears in the photograph with her husband.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike to attach to a compartment.

loans.name: Enkhbat

texts.en:
Enkhbat is 30 years old, lives with his wife and 2 infant children in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent, in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. His wife looks after their children at home. They don’t own land, therefore he works as a keeper of someone’s land, and lives there free of charge. At the same time he operates a tire repair service, which he has been doing since 2005.

A year ago he started reparing shock absorbers too, and he has a small garage which he built recently. The garage is currently unsuitable for working in cold weather. He is planning to make it warm and put some insulation in the walls and to fit a local heating system. One part of the loan he is asking for will be used to buy insulation and building materials. The other part will be used to increase his working capital by buying necessary spare parts and tools.

Enkhbat is a very optimistic person and he has been working hard to achieve his dreams.

loans.use: To purchase insulation and building materials for his garage and to increase his working capital.

loans.name: Pum

texts.en:
Mrs. Pum S. sells frying pans and stoves. She is 36 and is a single mother who cares for one child who is a pupil in the local public school. Mrs. Pum S.’s husband passed away many years ago. Since 2000, Mrs. Pum S. has sold her items around her village by motorcycle. She also orders products in bulk from retail door-to-door across the province. Mrs. Pum S. always takes a few weeks to sell their products.

Mrs. Pum S.'s business is now running very well because she sells her items at a reasonable price. Currently, her existing motorbike often breaks down during operation. Because of that, Mrs. Pum S. has decided to seek a loan from Kiva, which she will use to repair her broken motorcycle.

loans.use: To repair her broken motorcycle used to sell her products.

loans.name: Ker

texts.en:
Ker K., 47, is married and resides with her husband and child in Takeo Province, Cambodia, an area known for pre-angkorean Temples. K. is a farmer, earning an income of USD 4.00 per day. Her child is a phone repairman, earning an income of about USD 5.00 per day to help cover the family expenses. The family has to spend USD 80.00 on food, USD 5.00 on electricity and water supplies, and USD 20.00 on other necessary expenses every month.

K. is requesting a loan of USD 1,200 to purchase more phones to resell. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.  This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy phones to resell.

loans.name: Ilgar

texts.ru:
Ilgar M. 27 let. On jenat i imeyet 2 detey doch kotoroy 6 let ona idet v shkolu i sin kotoromu 4 qoda on idet v detskiy sadik. Ilgar yavlyayetsya IDP personom on pereselenec iz Fuzuli goroqa i seychas projivayet v Fuzuli region ,paselok Mahmudlu  vmeste s semyoy.

Ilgar uje 5 let kak zanimayestay etim biznessom skotovodstva. Etomu biznessu on nauchilsya u svoyeqo otca. Seychas On nujdayetsya v 2000 AZN chtobi kupit korovi dlya razvitiya svoyeqo biznessa.
texts.en:
Ilgar M. is 27 years old.  He is married and has 2 children: a 6-year-old daughter, who goes to school, and a 4-year-old son, who goes to kindergarten.  Ilgar is an IDP (Internally Displaced Person).  He is a refugee from the city of Fuzuli and now lives in the Fuzuli region, in Mahmudlu village, together with his family.

Ilgar has been involved in the animal husbandry business for 5 years.  He learned this business from his father.  Currently, he needs 2000 AZN in order to buy cattle and develop his business.

loans.use: Purchase of cattle

loans.name: Tem

texts.en:
Tem S., 45, is married and resides with her husband and six children in Takeo Province, Cambodia, an area known for pre-angkorean Temples. S. and her husband are farmers and raise cows, earning an income of USD 5.00 per day. Two of her children are employed as a driver and a garment factory worker, earning an income of about USD 4.00 per day. The family has to spend USD 30.00 on food, USD 10.00 on public transportation, and USD 15.00 on other necessary expenses every month.

S. is requesting a loan of USD 1,200 to purchase cows and a motorbike for the family's use. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia. S.'s husband appears in the photograph because S. was not available.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike and cows.

loans.name: Elizibith

texts.en: Elizibith L. is currently in the business of owning a grinding mill and food stalls at the market and is requesting a loan to stock more food stalls to sell more. Elizibith is 32 years old and is married with a husband that is a business man. She has 4 children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build up a house.

loans.use: To stock more food in her store to sell.

loans.name: Virginia

texts.en:
Virginia H. is from the village of Linconcomonan, Gingoog City. She is 42 years old. Virginia is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Virginia owns and operates a business venture in the food sector making and selling food. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling a variety of viands in different meals, and running a sari-sari store in the local community. Virginia has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Virginia joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Virginia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to invest in expanding the business. Virginia is requesting a new loan of 11,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. This loan will be the 3rd loan taken out by Virginia from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale.

loans.name: Tuy

texts.en:
Tuy K., 29, is married and resides with her husband and three children in Takeo Province, Cambodia, an area known for pre-Angkorean temples. K. sells fruit, earning an income of USD 6 per day. Her husband is a taxi driver, earning an income of about USD 10 per day. The family has to spend USD 30 on food, USD 5 on electricity and water, and USD 50 on other necessary expenses every month.  

K. is requesting a loan of USD 1200 to purchase a new car to operate her husband's business more efficiently. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.  This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia. K.'s husband appears in the photograph because K. was not available.

loans.use: buy a car to operate his taxi business more efficiently

loans.name: Rose

texts.en: Rose O.  is currently in the business of selling groundnut paste and local brew at the market and is requesting a loan to stock more bags of groundnuts to make paste to sell.  Rose is 32 years old and is widowed.   She has two children and one child goes to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to expand her business.

loans.use: Stock more bags of groundnuts to make paste to sell

loans.name: Uulkan's Group

texts.en:
Uulkan T. is the leader of this group. She is 27 and married. She has a daughter and a son. Three years ago with the initial investment of 3000 soms, Uulkan and her husband started to breed poultry. In the begining they had 30 hens and now they have increased that number to 70. Selling eggs and some hens, Uulkam makes 3750 soms per month. With money received from the loan she wants to purchase feed for the hens. In the future she plans to expand their family business and increase their flock to 500. 

Jumagul J. is the treasurer of the group. She is 46 and married. Her husband works as a post officer. They have two sons and a daughter. Seven years ago with the initial investment of 5000 soms, Jumagul rented a kiosk and started to sell convenience goods. In this way she makes 6000 soms per month.  That profit made it possible for her to save money and open her own shop. With money received from the loan, Jumagul wants to purchase convenience goods in order to increase the turnover of her business. 

Oktom U., 66, is married. She has a son who is a farmer. Oktom and her husband grow potatoes and breed cattle. They make money by selling potatoes and farm lafter fattening. Oktom hopes to obtain the loan because she needs money to cover her personals expenses. 

Buaisha U., 52, is married. She has two sons and two daughters. Buaisha and her husband are farmers. They grow potatoes and maize and breed livestock animals. With money received from the loan, they want to purchase two sheep in order to increase the number of their livestock. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 

MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase feed for hens

loans.name: Eddieza

texts.en:
Eddieza J. is from the village of Sta. Cruz, Magsaysay, Misamis Oriental. She is 30 years old. Eddieza is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Eddieza owns & operates a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling seafood products  including fish and shrimp, with her husband as the fisherman, in the local community. Eddieza has been engaged in her business for over 8 years and earns approximately 4000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Eddieza joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Eddieza has successfully repaid a previous loan of 13,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to invest in expanding the business. Eddieza is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase new tools for the maintenance of the boat. This will be the 3rd loan taken out by Eddieza from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand their business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.use: to purchase new tools for the maintenance of the boat

loans.name: Tebib

texts.ru:
Tebib Y. 35 let. On jenat i imeyet 2 detey sin kotoromu 7 let on uchitsya v shkole i doch kotoroy 2 qoda. Tabib jivet v Fizuli region, pasolok Bala Behmenli  vmeste so svoyey semyoy. 

Tabib uje 6 let rabotayet v etom biznesse prodaji produktov. Etomu biznessu on nauchilsya u svoyeqo otca. Eto uje vtoroy ssud Tabiba, v pervuyu ssudu on bral 1000 $, a seychas on nujdayetsya v 2000 AZN chtobi kupit produkt dlya svoyeqo maqazina , on xochet nachat prodavat v svayom maqazine takje moyushiye sredstva.

http://partners.kiva.org/lend/4798
texts.en:
Tebib Y. is 35 years old.  He is married and has 2 children: a 7-year-old son, who attends school and a 2-year-old daughter.  Tebib lives in the Fuzuli region, in the Bala Behmenli village together with his family.

Tebib has been working in the food products sale business for 6 years.  He learned this business from his father.  This is Tebib's second loan.  His first loan was for $1000, and now he needs 2000 AZN in order to buy food products for his store.  He wants to start selling cleaning supplies at his store.

loans.use: Purchase of products for resale

loans.name: Deborah

texts.en: Deborah is 35 years old. She has 3 children between the ages of 7 and 13. All her children go to school. She is married to a sewage operator. Deborah owns a mini-supermarket. She has adopted two orphans. With the loan she will buy more juice, biscuits, loaf breads, and milk to sell. With the profit she will save money. Her business is well known by her customers and the things that she sells are in high demand. She dreams of owning a boutique.

loans.use: To buy more juice, biscuits, loaf breads and milk to sell

loans.name: Regis

texts.en: Regis is 18 years old. She is married with one child. Her child is one year old and does not yet go to school. Regis sells new shoes. She has spent two years in this business. Her husband sells shoes with her. With the loan she will buy more shoes. She dreams of having a large business where she will be able to supply other retailers. With the profit she will buy more food for her family.

loans.use: To buy more shoes to sell

loans.name: Gulmairam's Group

texts.en:
Gulmairam O. is the leader of this group. She is 34 and married. She has three sons and a daughter. The sons are at school and the daughter is not yet. Gulmairam and her husband are farmers. They breed livestock. In order to make money Gulmairam sells about seven liters of milk per day. In this way she earns 2000 soms per month. With money received from the loan she wants to purchase five sheep for breeding. In the future she wants to provide her children with good education.

Dinara B. is the treasurer of the group. She is 36 and married. She has a daughter and a son. Both of them are at school. Dinara works as a nurse and her husband is a private driver. Dinara hopes to obtain the loan because she needs money to purchase cement and roofing slate for building a shed. 

Renat M. is 22. Four years ago with the initial investment of 20000 soms, he started to breed livestock.  He also provides transportation services to earn money. In this way he makes 2000 soms per month. With money received from the loan, he wants to purchase ten sheep in order to increase his flock. 

Abdysalam M., 39, is married. He has two daughters and a son. The first son is at school and the others are not yet. Abdysalam is engaged in cattle breeding; he also grows wheat and maize. His wife sells 40 liter of milk every day, in this way she makes 8000 soms per month. With money received from the loan, Abdysalam wants to purchase cattle for breeding. In the future he wants to purchase a flat in Bishkek.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 

MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. loans.name: Lliminata

texts.en:
Lliminata is 34 years old. She is married to a farmer. They have three children between the ages of 4 and 8 years. One of her children goes to school, but the others are yet to start because they are still young. 

She sells a variety of items in her shop. With the loan, she will buy lotions, salt, soaps and juice to sell. She has good customer service, that is why most of the people know her and like her business. 

With the profit, she will pay school fees for her children. She would like to have a big sum of a loan so that she can boost her business.

loans.use: To buy more lotions, soap and juices to sell

loans.name: Nhem

texts.en: Nhem R. is 50 years old, married and devoted to three children who are employed in different jobs. She stays at home to manage the family housework as well as selling some fruit to her villagers for income. She is married to 54-year-old Ket Chhoum, who helps her in picking up fruit from the wholesalers. Nhem R. always hired the motor taxi for transport her products to the market because she doesn’t have her own vehicle to transport her items. To solve the problem, Nhem R. has requested a loan in the amount of $1,000 to be used to buy a used motorcycle to provide transportation without hiring a taxi.

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and as working capital

loans.name: Amalia

texts.en:
Amalia A. is from the village of San Andres, Kadingilan, Bukidnon. She is 39 years old. Amalia is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Amalia owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector running a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling both food & daily use products in the local community. Amalia has been engaged in her business for over 1 year and earns approximately 5000 PHP per month for these activities.

In 2010, Amalia joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Amalia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell in her shop. Amalia is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP which will be used as working capital and to purchase additional inventory. This loan will be the 2nd loan taken out by Amalia from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and working capital.

loans.name: Jovie

texts.en:
Jovie L. is from the village of Kipaducan, Pangantucan, Bukidnon. She is 27 years old. Jovie is married and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Jovie owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector running a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling both food & daily use products in the local community. Jovie has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP per month for these activities.

In 2009, Jovie joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Jovie has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell in her shop. Jovie is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory & working capital. This loan will be the 3rd loan taken out by Jovie from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and working capital.

loans.name: Fanny

texts.en:
Fanny M. is from the village of Poblacion, Dangcagan, Bukidnon. She is 42 years old. Fanny is separated from her spouse and has 2 adult-aged children. To make a living, Fanny owns & operates a business venture in the food sector operating a restaurant. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from serving a variety of different meals to customers in the local community. Fanny has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 10000 PHP per month for these activities.

In 2010, Fanny joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Fanny is requesting a new loan of 4000 PHP which will be used to purchase food & beverages for the restaurant. This loan will be the 1st loan taken out by Fanny from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase food & beverages for the restaurant.

loans.name: Sharapiya

texts.en:
Sharapiya M. is the single mother of three daughters. She was the victim of domestic violence, however her life became stable after divorcing her husband. In 2005, in order to find means of subsistence for her children, Sharapiya started a cattle breeding business, and bought bull calves for fattening and reselling. She worked hard and managed to maintain and develop the farm and renovate her house. Also, Sharapiya is fond of cultivating flowers and made her hobby a small source of income. Now Sharapiya wants to use this loan of 60,000 KGS to buy more bull calves and forage for her cattle. With the revenue from this loan, she plans to pay for the education of her daughters. Sharapiya is full of energy and ready for the many achievements coming her way.

Bai-Tushum and Partners use Kiva funding to target especially vulnerable population in Kyrgystan. It is one of the leading Microfinance Institutions in Kyrgyzstan. As a reliable financial partner, Bai-Tushum contributes to the economic development of the Kyrgyz Republic through the delivery of microfinance services in rural and urban areas that lead to increased employment and meet the interests of its clients and investors.

loans.use: To purchase cattle.

loans.name: Hagigat

texts.ru:
Hagigat X. 47 let. Ona zamujem i imeyet 3 detey. Hagigat yavlyayetsya IDP personom ona pereselenec iz Fuzuli  qoroda, seychas projivayet v Fuzuli regione vmeste s semyoy.

Hagigat uje 7 let kak zanimayetsya etim biznessom skotovodstva. V yeyo rabote yey pomoqayet  doch kotoroy 19 let. Etomu biznessu ona nauchilas u sestri. Seychas Hagigat nujdayetsya v 2000 AZN chtobi kupit korovi dlya razvitiya svoyeqo biznesa.
texts.en:
Hagigat X. is 47 years old.  She is married and has 3 children.  Hagigat is an IDP (Internally Displaced Person).  She is a refugee from the city of Fuzuli and now lives in the Fuzuli region together with her family.

Hagigat has been involved in the animal husbandry business for 7 years.  Her 19-year-old daughter helps her with the work.  Hagigat learned this business from her sister.  Now Hagigat needs 2000 AZN in order to buy cattle for developing her business.

loans.use: Purchase of cattle

loans.name: Gibson Muasa

texts.en: Gibson Muasa M. is a 35 year old café owner and fish monger in Kilifi. He is married to Mueni Muasa who contributes to the family’s total income; the couple supports six people. He has been in this business for the last five years and he is doing great. This is his third loan from KADET. Gibson would like to purchase a deep freezer with the loan money and buy more fish inventory for his shop. He will use the anticipated profits to start a saloon business for his wife. In future he hopes the business will be fully expanded and that he will be in a position to cater for all of his family's needs.

loans.use: To buy a deep freezer to stock the fish that he sells.

loans.name: Nyawa

texts.en:
Nyawa M. is a 33 year old single man who was introduced to KADET LTD by another existing client who is with KADET LTD. He sells second hand clothes in Gongoni Malindi town, whereby his main customers are Malindi town dwellers and passersby. The business has been operating for the past three years now and the gentleman wishes to expand it with the loan that he has taken, which is his first one.

Mr. Nyawa’s loan amounts to Kshs. 20,000 which he intends to use to buy more stock of clothes for sale to sustain business, and also to repair his business stall so that the business can grow. The businessman wishes to use the anticipated profit to further grow his business and hopes that one day, he may get to own a well-established clothes shop in the area.

loans.use: To buy more stock of clothes for sale, and repair the business stall.

loans.name: Zaina

texts.en:
Zaina Nanjjuko is 21 years old and lives in the town of Kalerwe in the Kampala east region of Uganda. She is single and has 2 children. All of her children are currently in school. Zaina has a business of selling drinks, which she has had for 5 years.         

To help expand her business, Zaina has requested a loan of 200,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more drinks like soda. With the help of the loan from BRAC, Zaina hopes to generate greater profits and pay school fees. In the future, Zaina hopes to open another business like selling clothes. Zaina is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by learning how to save money.

loans.use: To buy more drinks like soda to sell.

loans.name: Juliet

texts.en:
Juliet Kobusinye is 20 years old and lives in the town of Kalerwe in the Kampala east region of Uganda. She is married and has 2 children. All of her children are currently in school. Juliet has a business of selling drinks, which she has had for 1 year.         

To help expand her business, Juliet has requested a loan of 200,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more sodas and passion fruits. With the help of the loan from BRAC, Juliet hopes to generate greater profits and sometimes buy food. In the future, Juliet hopes to expand her business to a shop. Juliet is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by expanding her business.

loans.use: To buy more sodas and passion fruits to sell.

loans.name: Annet

texts.en:
Annet S. is 20 years old and lives in the town of Kalerwe in the Kampala east region of Uganda.  She is single and has 2 children, who are both currently in school. Annet has a business of selling second hand clothes, which she has had for 3 years.         

To help expand her business, Annet has requested a loan of 200,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more clothes. With the help of the loan from BRAC, Annet hopes to generate greater profits and sometimes buy food. In the future, Annet hopes to own a house. Annet is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by learning how to work hard.

loans.use: To buy more clothes to sell.

loans.name: Matlubakhon

texts.en:
Matlubakhon is not married and lives with her family, including her parents and brothers. She runs a small business selling perfumes, cosmetics, wedding gifts, kids’ toys and others. Her business is located at the central market in Shahrituz, Tajikistan. This good location brings in many customers and makes her business a success. Matlubakhon has been in this business for 5 years. The business brings a stable income to Matlubakhon's family. Her goal is to develop the business further, rent a larger facility, and begin selling items in bulk. She would like to borrow $2,500 USD to purchase more inventory. Matlubakhon hopes to increase her sales and earn additional income.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International:

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists, and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History:

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Increase stock by purchasing goods to sell.

loans.name: Lala

texts.ru:
Lala B. 29 let. Ona zamujem i imeyet 2 detey sin kotoromu 7 let i doch kotoroy 5 let. Lala yavlyayetsya IDP personom ona pereselenec iz Fuzuli qoroda, seychas projivayet v Fuzuli regione, paselok Gobcuk vmeste s semyoy.

Lala uje 4 qoda zanimayetsya etim biznessom prodaji produktov. Etomu biznessu ona nauchilas u brata. Seychas ona nujdayetsya v 2000 AZN chtobi kupit produkti dlya prodaji.
texts.en:
Lala B. is 29 years old.  She is married and has 2 children: 7-year-old son and 5-year-old daughter.  Lala is an IDP (Internally Displaced Person).  She is a refugee from the city of Fuzuli and now lives in the Gobcuk village in the Fuzuli region together with her family.

Lala has been involved in the food sales business for 4 years.  She learned this business from her brother.  Now she needs 2000 AZN in order to buy food products for resale.

loans.use: Purchase of products for resale

loans.name: Islomidin

texts.en:
Islomidin S. is 39 years old and married with three school-aged children. Islomidin has been in the business of selling cows for over eight years. He buys them from villagers and throughout the nearby province to raise them for resale to abattoirs and farmers. His wife has been a fruit seller for two years. Islomidin is requesting a loan of $1,500 USD to purchase additional cows. This loan will allow Islomidin to expand his business and better provide for his family.

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase cows for resale

loans.name: Rafoatkhon

texts.en:
Rafoatkhon is married with two children. She runs a small business selling groceries at a local market. Rafoatkhon has been in this business for 10 years. She is very industrious and a hard worker. Her integrity, determination and perseverance have ensured the sustainability and growth of her business. Rafoatkhon has gradually been able to save some money and reinvest it in her business. Between these savings and loans from IMON International, she has been able to increase her inventory and sales volume. Rafoatkhon is requesting a loan for 12,000 Somoni that will allow her to increase her assortment of inventory. She is planning to buy food products wholesale for further retail sales. This loan will help Rafoatkhon increase her inventory and cater to an ever-increasing number of customers, further promoting stable expansion for her business.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase foodstuffs to increase the range of products

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary A. is 26 years old and married with a husband who is in the army. She has one child who does not go to school. Mary is currently in the business of selling charcoal and is requesting a loan to stock more bags of charcoal to sell. With the extra profits from her loan, Mary hopes to be able to build a house.

loans.use: To stock more bags of charcoal to sell

loans.name: Yaiko Porave Rekavo (In Search Of A Better Life) Group

texts.es:
El Comité de Mujeres de nombre Jaiko Porave Rekavo (En busca de una vida mejor) se conformó en fecha 24 de setiembre del 2.010, se encuentran en el 1º ciclo, en forma conjunta y solidaria dentro del programa.
Además del trabajo independiente de cada una, también desarrollan actividades en forma conjunta  para recaudar fondos con el fin de contar con un capital dentro del grupo, a la vez se ayudan mutuamente para llegar a los objetivos que es la de trabajar para apoyar económicamente  a sus familias en especial.
La Sr. Isidora es una de las integrantes y quien trabajo mucho para la conformación del comité, es una de las señoras más activas y es la presidenta del grupo.
Ella se dedica  a la venta de minicarga para celulares para desde su casa, esta actividad consiste en que personas que utilizar varias líneas de telefonía celular prepagos compran saldo para sus líneas y ella provee.
Según, ella esta actividad le beneficia mucho y le conviene seguir con ella ya que le ayudará  con el ingreso de la familia.
Solicita el préstamo para la compra de saldo para su teléfono ya que quiere ampliar el monto que tiene disponible para sus clientes.
Según la Sra. Isidora las actividades que realizan entre las compañeras son muy útiles para el desarrollo personal de cada una.
texts.en:
This group of women has named themselves Jaiko Porave Rekavo (meaning In search of a better life). It was created on September 24, 2010 and they are on their first loan cycle, working together as a group in the program. 

Aside from their individual businesses they also work together to raise funds to have a cache within the group. They help each other to reach their goals, especially when working to support their families.

Isidora is a member of the group and she worked very hard in the formation of the group. She is one of the most active members and she is also the leader of the group. She sells prepaid cell phone card from her home. Her business sis based on the fact that people can use various brands of prepaid phone cards and she is able to provide these to her customers. She states that her business is of great benefit to her because she is able to have a source of income for her family.  She requests a loan to purchase phone cards to have a larger inventory available for her clients. 

According to Isidora her colleagues all have businesses that are instrumental in their personal development.

loans.use: To purchase prepaid cell phone cards for resale.

loans.name: Annet

texts.en:
Annet N. is 22 years old and lives in the town of Kireka in the Kampala East region of Uganda. She is single and has one child who is not currently in school. For the past two years, Annet has run a business making charcoal stoves. 

To help expand her business, Annet has requested a loan of 200,000 UGX from BRAC Uganda to purchase more clay soil. With the help of the loan from BRAC, Annet hopes to generate greater profits and buy food. In the future, Annet hopes to expand her business.   

Annet is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by teaching her how to be more responsible.

loans.use: to buy more clay soil

loans.name: Hidia

texts.en: Hidia S. is 26 years old and is married with six children, two of whom go to school. Her husband is a businessman. Hidia is currently in the business of selling clothes and tea on the street. She is requesting a loan to stock more clothes to sell. With the extra profits from her loan, Hidia hopes to be able to buy a plot of land in the future.

loans.use: To stock more clothes to sell

loans.name: Justine

texts.en:
Justine A. is 21 years old and lives in the town of Kireka in the Kampala East region of Uganda.  She is married and has two children.  One of her children is currently in school.  Justine has a business making charcoal stoves, which she has had for four years.         

To help expand her business, Justine has requested a loan of 200,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to purchase more clay soil.  With the help of the loan from BRAC, Justine hopes to generate greater profits and pay for school fees and food.  In the future, Justine hopes to own a salon or a tailoring shop.  Justine is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by changing her life. She now has a good meal in time and good shelter for her family from the loan she received.

loans.use: To buy more clay soil

loans.name: Esperanza Group

texts.es:
El comité  se formó mediante la ganas de las señoras de integrar el Programa de comité de Mujeres Emprendedoras  y asi todas se apoyaron, y actualmente se encuentrar trabajando en varias actividades ya que el objetivo del pragrama es la de capacitar a las señora para que tengan alguna actividad que les pueda generar ingreso y de esa manera ayudar a sus familias.
Así las integrantes de este comité tiene objetivo principal el crecimiento de cada una de ellas, tanto social como económicamente, son reconocidas en el lugar como mujeres muy trabajadoras.
La Sra. Lilian, presidenta del grupo tiene 35 años, ella esta domiciliada  de Guarambaré, alli tambien tiene su  taller de cotillón,  donde fabrica y vende articulos decorativos para cumpleaños, quinceaños, bodas  y otras fiestas, es una mujer emprendedora e innovadora.
Sus fabricaciones son muy admiradas por los clientes por lo constantemente tiene pedidos, y de esta forma ella obtiene ingresos muy buenos para su familias.
Solicita el prestamo para la compra de los accesorios que ella utiliza para la fabricación de los centros de mesas, sorpresas para cumpleaños, piñatas, y otros.
texts.en:
This group formed by women who wanted to create a committee of female entrepreneurs.  They all support each other and are currently working on several activities.  The objective of the program is to train women to have an activity that allows them to generate income and help their families.  The members' main objective is the growth of each person, both socially and economically.  They are recognized locally as very hardworking women.

Lilian is the president of the group.  She is 35 years old and lives in Guarambaré.  She also has a party favor workshop there, where she manufactures and sells decorations for birthdays, quinceaños [fifteenth birthday parties], weddings, and other parties.  She is a hardworking and innovative woman.  Her products are admired by her customers and she always has orders. She earns a good income for her family.

She is asking for this loan to purchase accessories to use in the manufacture of centerpieces, birthday party favors, piñatas, and more decorations.

loans.use: Purchase of paper, adhesives, tapes, and other things for the manufacture of center pieces, piñatas, and more.

loans.name: Hidia

texts.en: Hidia S. is 32 years old and married with five children. Her husband is serving in the army and all of her children attend school. Hidia is currently in the business of selling various goods at a shop and is requesting a loan to stock more items to sell such as bags of sugar, soap etc. With the extra profits from her loan, Hidia hopes to be able to build a house.

loans.use: Tp stock more items to sell such as bags of sugar, soap etc.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Car maintenance

loans.name: Takku Liggey Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe de solidarité TAKKU LIGGEY est créé le 27 septembre 2009. Il est composé de 13 femmes qui sont toutes issues du même village. Elles se sont organisées par affinité et par proximité et partagent le même centre d'intérêt qui est le développement de leur terroir. 

Madame Amy Lô debout tout à fait à droit de la photo responsable du groupe. Elle est âgée de 53 ans. Elle est mariée et mère de 6 enfants.

Elle fait de la transformation et vente d'huile d'arachide. Elle écoule sa marchandise sur place dans le village. Elle fait aussi de la restauration dans le village.

Avec son nouveau crédit elle va augmenter son niveau de production en achetant plus d'arachide. Elle va également améliorer son petit restaurant. 

Son objectif est de soutenir son mari dans la prise en charge familiale
texts.en:
The TAKKU LIGGEY solidarity group was created September 27, 2009. It is composed of 13 women who all hail from the same village. They got organized based on affinities and proximity and share a common interest for developing their region.

Mrs. Amy Lô, who stands all the way to the right of the photo, is the group leader. She is 53 years old. She is married and a mother of six children.

She transforms and sells peanut oil. She sells her merchandise locally in the village. She also serves food in the village.

With her new credit, she will increase her production level by buying more peanuts. She will also improve her small restaurant.

Her objective is to assist her husband in supporting the family.

loans.use: Buy peanuts to transform into oil

loans.name: Annet

texts.en:
Annet N. is 22 years old and lives in the town of Kireka in the Kampala East region of Uganda.  She is married and has three children.  Two of her children are currently in school.  Annet has a business making charcoal stoves, which she has had for six years.         

To help expand her business, Annet has requested a loan of 200,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to purchase more clay soil.  With the help of the loan from BRAC, Annet hopes to generate greater profits and pay school fees.  In the future, Annet hopes to learn more about hairdressing. Annet is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by expanding her business more than before.

loans.use: To buy more clay soil

loans.name: John

texts.en:
M. John is a hard working and an ever-optimistic 33-year-old married father of four children. He operates a growing agro produce business in Kitooma, Ibanda dealing in agriculture produce, especially rice. 

With a business longevity span of 10 years, John has managed to significantly sustain and improve his family’s welfare status through paying his bills and general family welfare. To all appearances, his future business prospects are promising with 250,000 Ugandan shillings coming in monthly out of his business. He envisions an even greater profit margin as he gets this loan, anticipating being in position to buy more stock of beans, maize and groundnuts for the business. This will enable him to expand business by opening up more stores and being able to earn more revenue and live a self-sustaining life.

loans.use: To purchase more beans, maize and groundnuts for his business

loans.name: Cecilia

texts.en: Cecilia G. is currently in the business of baking local Sudanese bread such as tamia, gelabia etc and is requesting a loan to stock more baking flour to sell.  Cecilia is 30 years old and is married to an army man. She has six children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house.

loans.use: To stock more baking flour

loans.name: Silna

texts.en:
Silna E. is currently in the business of selling and weaving hair in a salon shop. She is requesting a loan to stock more weaving materials and other necessary tools.  

Silna is 28 years old and married to a local government staff member. She has one child and her child goes to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to expand the business.

loans.use: Stock more weaving materials and other necessary tools

loans.name: Ko'e Pyahu Kuñakuerape Group

texts.es:
Las mujeres del presente comité son de Piribebuy.
Las señoras de este comité son mujeres muy honestas y sacrificadas, cada una de ellas trabajan arduamente para aumentar sus ingresos y así aportar un poco más a su unidad familiar, algunas salen a vender comestibles, otras venden ropas, otras tienen pequeñas despensas y kioscos y las demás se dedican a la fabricación y venta de detergentes, suavizantes, desodorante de ambiente etc.  
Las integrantes del comité están muy felices de participar del programa y están muy agradecidas con Fundación Paraguaya por tan importante apoyo que les está brindando.  
Una de las integrantes es la Sra. Rossana quien se dedica a la venta de ropas desde ya hace bastante tiempo y teniendo en cuenta la calidad y precios bajos de sus mercaderías posee una buena clientela.
La misma desea incrementar sus ingresos mediante la adquisición al por mayor cantidad y variedad de mercaderías de la temporada primavera-verano, para satisfacer la demanda y tambie para abaratar los precios.
Solicita el préstamo para la compra de mercaderias como remeras, shorts, blusas, vestidos, y otros.
De esta forma seguirá ampliando el negocio.
texts.en:
The women of this committee are from Piribebuy. They are honest and selfless; each works very hard to raise her income and thus contribute a little more to her family. Some go out to sell food, others sell clothing, others have small general stores and kiosks, and the rest make and sell detergents, fabric softeners, air fresheners, etc. 

The members of the committee are very pleased to be participating in the program and are very grateful to the Paraguay Foundation for the important support that it provides them. 

One of the members is Ms. Rossana, who has sold clothing for a long time. She has built a good clientele because she sells quality merchandise at low prices. Rossana wants to increase her income through the wholesale purchase of a large quantity and variety of spring-summer merchandise, thereby satisfying demand and lowering prices. 

She requests the loan to purchase merchandise such as t-shirts, shorts, blouses, and dresses. In doing so, Rossana will continue growing her business.

loans.use: To purchase clothes in bulk for the spring-summer season to resell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Car maintenance

loans.name: Anonymous
